answers.answer: It sounds as if he has Hyperadrenocorticism, aka: Cushing's Syndrome, or other endocrine disorder.  These diseases are not diagnosed with routine blood work.  The episodes in which he urinates out of control, could be due to a seizure disorder, which is unrelated to the other symptoms.  It would be best to have this sorted out by your vet.  Endocrine disorders cannot be totally controlled with homeopathy or holistic therapies, but homoeopathy and holistic therapies can help.

Could this be a possible thyroid problem? Maybe you could have that checked. Also, rule out diabetes. I would also find out whether his uncontrolled urination is caused by something specific to his bladder, whether it's as a result of drinking copious amounts of water, or whether there is some level of mental confusion, which could happen if there was any kidney trouble.Is the homoepathic medicine called NATRIUM MURIATICUM? (Nat. Mur.)? And what potency has been prescribed?  If 30c, it might be good to try a lower potency -say 6c? You should speak to your alternative Practitioner about it.Also, with Homoepathic meds, occasionally a state can occur known as "Proving" when the symptoms are exacerbated, and the meds have the opposite reaction to the one desired. The way to handle "proving" is to stop the medication straight away, then only start again if/when the original symptoms recur. But you need to speak to the practitioner about all this, as I'm not an expert.If he is taking straight kelp (as opposed to homoeopathic-dose kelp) -then that is a little salty, and could be causing fluid retention and increased thirst.
